subject: Photography
title: William Klein: Anti-Photography
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on William Klein: Anti-Photography.

hook.text: He overexposed, blurred, cropped wildly, and broke every composition rule. Then he published a masterpiece.

buildup.text: William Klein was a painter who picked up a camera in New York and shot the city like a visual assault.

discovery.text: His 1956 book 'Life Is Good & Good for You in New York' was chaotic, aggressive, and unlike anything before.

twist.text: American publishers rejected it. It was published in France and won the Prix Nadar. Irony sharp as his images.

climax.text: Klein influenced generations of street photographers who learned that energy matters more than elegance.

punchline.text: He photographed New York like New York feels: loud.

quiz.question: What happened when Klein tried to publish his New York book in America?
options: American publishers rejected it; it was published in France instead
It was banned by the government
